Abstract: This study delves into the intricate mechanisms of visual representations within the human brain, employing advanced neural decoding techniques and multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) to unravel the complex dynamics of object representations. By analyzing the representational structure of neural activity, we aim to shed light on how internal representations of visual stimuli are encoded, maintained, and transformed across different brain regions. Our research leverages cutting-edge methodologies to decode the neural signatures associated with various objects, providing insights into the temporal and spatial dynamics of neural processing. The findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the neural underpinnings of visual perception, highlighting the sophisticated interplay between neural dynamics and representational fidelity. This work not only advances our knowledge of the brain's visual system but also opens new avenues for exploring the principles underlying neural coding and the organization of internal representations in the context of visual cognition.
